item.title: Example Page 1
item.description:
In this tutorial, I'll share my top 10 tips for getting started with Academic:

Tip 1

item.title: Example Talk
item.description:
Click on the Slides button above to view the built-in slides feature.

Slides can be added in a few ways:

  • Create slides using Academic's Slides feature and link using slides parameter in the front matter of the talk file
  • Upload an existing slide deck to static/ and link using url_slides parameter in the front matter of the talk file
  • Embed your slides (e.g. Google Slides) or presentation video on this page using shortcodes.

Further talk details can easily be added to this page using Markdown and $\rm \LaTeX$ math code.

item.title: Note10 Kaplan Meier Estimation
item.description:
• KM Estimation is a non-parametric estimation of survival function.

  • when no event times are censored, a non-parametric estimator of S(T) is \(1-F_{n}(t)\), where \(F_{n}(t)\) is the empirical cumulative distribution function.

  • when some observations are censored, we can estimate S(t) using KM estimation.

Let: \(n_i\) be number of objects at risk of dying at time \(t_i\)
\(d_i\) be number of events that occur at time \(t_i\)

KM estimator

\(\hat{S}(t) = \prod_{k=1}^i \frac{n_k - d_k}{n_k}\)

Basic tests for difference in survival curves

Want to test:
\(H_0: S_1(t) = S_2(t)\)
\(H_1: S_1(t) \neq S_2(t)\)

mydat <- matrix(c('d1i','d2i','n1i-d1i','n2i-d2i'),ncol = 2, byrow = T)
colnames(mydat) <- c('Group 1', 'Group 2')
rownames(mydat) <- c('Died','Survived')
mydat
##          Group 1   Group 2  
## Died     "d1i"     "d2i"    
## Survived "n1i-d1i" "n2i-d2i"

Test Statistic:
\(Q = \frac{(\sum w_i (d_{1i} - \hat{e}_{1i}))^2}{\sum w_i ^2 \hat{v}_{1i}}\) where:
\(\hat{e}_{1i} = \frac{n_{1i}d_{1i}}{n_{i}}\)

\(\hat{v}_{1i} = \frac{n_{1i}n_{2i}d_i (n_i - d_i)}{n_i ^2 (n_i - 1)}\)

\(w_i =\) some weighting functing

Tests:
Log-rank: \(w_i = 1\)
Wilcoxon: \(w_i = n_i\)
Tarone-ware: \(w_i = \sqrt{n_i}\)
Peto-Peto: \(w_i = \prod_{i=1}^T (\frac{1-\hat{e}_i}{n_i + 1})\)

item.title: Note9 Intro to Survival Analysis
item.description:
Time to Event Data

Keywords: Failure, Lifetime Data, Time-event, Time-to-event-data

  • Outcome: Time until some events occures -> survival analysis.

  • In order to measure survival time, need a begining(t=0) and end(t = T).

  • t=0 is when the clock starts.

  • t=T is when the event occurs(or censored) + clock stops.

  • Between this two times(t - T), the subject is said to be “at risk” for the event.

  • Survival time T is the difference between these two points.

  • Usually measured in days, months or years.

Question: Time is continuous, why not using linear regression?

Answer: Censoring! If no censoring, you can use it!

Censoring

Right Censored(by for the most common)

  • known survival time is greater than some value: T > a

Left Censored(rare)

  • known survival time is less than some value: T < b

Interval Censored

  • known survival time is within some interval: a < T < b

Functions of Survival Time

  • PDF: f(t)

  • CDF: F(t) = P(T<t)

  • Survival Function S(t): S(t) = P(T>t) = 1 - F(t), this is the prob that people survived passed t.

  • Unconditional probability failure rate f(t): \(f(t) = \lim_{\Delta t\to\ 0}\frac{P(t \leq T \leq t + \Delta t)}{\Delta t}\)

But, subjects who have died before time t are no longer at risk during (t, t + t).
So it make sense to think of a conditional failure rate.

  • Conditional failure rate: risk of an event occuring at time t, given the subject has survived to time t.

  • Hazard Function h(t)

\(h(t) = \lim_{\Delta t\to\ 0}\frac{P(t \leq T \leq t + \Delta t | T \geq t)}{\Delta t}\), h(t) > 0, h(t) is not a probability. The hazard function, h(t), is the instantaneous rate at which events occur, given no previous events.

  • Cumulative Hazard Function H(t)

\(H(t) = \int\limits_{0}^{t} h(u) du\)

  • Relationships between S(t), H(t), h(t), f(t)

\(h(t) = - \frac{\partial log(S(t))}{\partial t} = \frac{f(t)}{S(t)}\)

\(H(t) = -log(S(t))\)

\(S(t) = exp(-H(t))\)

\(f(t) = - \frac{\partial S(t)}{\partial t}\)

Comment for Survival Distributions

Distribution h(t) S(t) f(t)
Exponential \(\lambda\) \(exp(-\lambda t)\) \(\lambda exp(-\lambda t)\)
Weibull $t^{-1} $ \(exp(-\lambda t^\alpha)\) \(\alpha \lambda t^{\alpha -1}exp(-\lambda t^\alpha)\)
Gompertze \(\theta exp(\alpha t)\) \(exp(\frac{\theta}{\alpha}(1-exp(\alpha t)))\) \(\theta exp(\alpha t)exp(\frac{\theta}{\alpha}(1-exp(\alpha t)))\)

Others: Gamma, lognormal, log-logistic, inverse gaussian, Pareto

item.title: An example preprint / working paper
item.description:
Click the Slides button above to demo Academic's Markdown slides feature.

Supplementary notes can be added here, including code and math.

item.title: Slides
item.description:
Create slides in Markdown with Academic

Academic | Documentation

Features

  • Efficiently write slides in Markdown
  • 3-in-1: Create, Present, and Publish your slides
  • Supports speaker notes
  • Mobile friendly slides

Controls

  • Next: Right Arrow or Space
  • Previous: Left Arrow
  • Start: Home
  • Finish: End
  • Overview: Esc
  • Speaker notes: S
  • Fullscreen: F
  • Zoom: Alt + Click
  • PDF Export: E

Code Highlighting

Inline code: variable

Code block:

porridge = "blueberry"
if porridge == "blueberry":
    print("Eating...")

Math

In-line math: $x + y = z$

Block math:

$$ f\left( x \right) = ;\frac{{2\left( {x + 4} \right)\left( {x - 4} \right)}}{{\left( {x + 4} \right)\left( {x + 1} \right)}} $$

Fragments

Make content appear incrementally

{{% fragment %}} One {{% /fragment %}}
{{% fragment %}} **Two** {{% /fragment %}}
{{% fragment %}} Three {{% /fragment %}}

Press Space to play!

One Two Three

A fragment can accept two optional parameters:

  • class: use a custom style (requires definition in custom CSS)
  • weight: sets the order in which a fragment appears

Speaker Notes

Add speaker notes to your presentation

{{% speaker_note %}}
- Only the speaker can read these notes
- Press `S` key to view
{{% /speaker_note %}}

Press the S key to view the speaker notes!

  • Only the speaker can read these notes
  • Press S key to view

Themes

  • black: Black background, white text, blue links (default)
  • white: White background, black text, blue links
  • league: Gray background, white text, blue links
  • beige: Beige background, dark text, brown links
  • sky: Blue background, thin dark text, blue links
  • night: Black background, thick white text, orange links
  • serif: Cappuccino background, gray text, brown links
  • simple: White background, black text, blue links
  • solarized: Cream-colored background, dark green text, blue links

Custom Slide

Customize the slide style and background

{{< slide background-image="/img/boards.jpg" >}}
{{< slide background-color="#0000FF" >}}
{{< slide class="my-style" >}}

Custom CSS Example

Let's make headers navy colored.

Create assets/css/reveal_custom.css with:

.reveal section h1,
.reveal section h2,
.reveal section h3 {
  color: navy;
}

Questions?

Ask

Documentation

Donec ut efficitur arcu, in malesuada neque. Nunc dignissim nisl massa, id vulputate nunc pretium nec. Quisque eget urna in risus suscipit ultricies. Pellentesque odio odio, tincidunt in eleifend sed, posuere a diam. Nam gravida nisl convallis semper elementum. Morbi vitae felis faucibus, vulputate orci placerat, aliquet nisi. Aliquam erat volutpat. Maecenas sagittis pulvinar purus, sed porta quam laoreet at.
